natural problem: Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$?
natural solution: When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus, \[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$ Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get

\begin{align} 19a + b &= P(19) = 99, \\ 99a + b &= P(99) = 19. \end{align}Subtracting the equations, we get $80a = -80,$ so $a = -1.$  Then $-19 + b = 99,$ so $b = 118.$  Hence, the remainder is $\boxed{-x + 118}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "P x mod (x - 19) = 99"
and h1 : "P x mod (x - 99) = 19"
shows  "P x mod ((x - 19)*(x - 99)) = -x + 118"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$? The final Answer is -x + 118
 ### Proof
 By the Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$
 When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus, \[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$ Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get

 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "P x mod (x - 19) = 99"
and h1 : "P x mod (x - 99) = 19"
shows  "P x mod ((x - 19)*(x - 99)) = -x + 118"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two equations where $P(x) \mod (x - 19) = 99$ and $P(x) \mod (x - 99) = 19$, find $x$ such that $P(x) \mod [(x - 19) * (x - 99)] = -x + 118$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * Q x + 99"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 99) * R x + 19"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * (x - 99) * S x + T x"
shows  "\<forall> x. T x = -x + 118"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * Q(x) + 99"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 99) * S(x) + 19"
and h2 : "P x dvd (x - 19) * (x - 99)"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * (x - 99) * T x"
shows  "R x = -x + 118"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$? The final Answer is -x + 118

 *)

fixes x P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * Q(x) + 99"

and h2 : "P x dvd (x - 19) * (x - 99)"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * (x - 99) * T x"
shows  "R x = -x + 118"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

The final answer is that $r = -x + 118$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x - 19) = 99"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. P x mod (x - 99) = 19"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. a = P x mod (x - 19) * (x - 99)"
and h3 : "\<forall>x. b = P x mod (x - 99) * (x - 19)"
shows  "\<forall>x. a - b = -x + 118"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$? The final Answer is -x + 118
 ### Proof

 *)

and h3 : "\<forall>x. b = P x mod (x - 99) * (x - 19)"
shows  "\<forall>x. a - b = -x + 118"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

Define $a$ and $b$ as $a = P(x) \mod (x - 19) \times (x - 99)$ and $b = P(x) \mod (x - 99) \times (x - 19)$ respectively. Find a relationship between $a$, $b$, and $x$. The final answer is $a - b = -x + 118$.

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (\<exists> q1::real. P x = (x - 19) * q1 + 99)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (\<exists> q2::real. P x = (x - 99) * q2 + 19)"
shows  "\<exists> q3::real. \<forall> x. P x = (x - 19) * (x - 99) * q3 - x + 118"

(* ### Problem

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Given a real function $P(x)$ which satisfies two properties:

1. For every $x$, there exists a real number $q1$ such that $P(x) = (x - 19) * q1 + 99$.
2. For every $x$, there exists a real number $q2$ such that $P(x) = (x - 99) * q2 + 19$.

Find a real number $q3$ such that for every $x$, $P(x) = (x - 19) * (x - 99) * q3 - x + 118$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : " \<forall> x. P x mod (x - 19) = 99"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 99) = 19"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 19) * (x - 99)) = -x + 118"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$? The final Answer is -x + 118
 ### Proof
 By the Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$
 When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus, \[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$ Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get

 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : " \<forall> x. P x mod (x - 19) = 99"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. P x mod (x - 99) = 19"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x mod ((x - 19) * (x - 99)) = -x + 118"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a real-valued function $P(x)$. If for all $x$, the remainder of $P(x)$ divided by $(x-19)$ is $99$ and the remainder of $P(x)$ divided by $(x-99)$ is $19$, prove that for all $x$, the remainder of $P(x)$ divided by the product of $(x-19)$ and $(x-99)$ equals $-x+118$.
